qas.question: What is the National Portrait Gallery known for housing?

answers.text: depictions of figures from British history

qas.question: London's Tate Britain and Tate Modern galleries were formerly one entity known as what?
What cultural and scientific hub was named in honor of Queen Victoria's husband?
What London museum was named for an historic Queen of England and her Prince husband?

answers.text: the Victoria and Albert Museum (for the applied arts)

qas.question: What was the original purpose for the construction of the Tate Gallery?

answers.text: as an annexe of the National Gallery

context: In the latter half of the 19th century the locale of South Kensington was developed as "<a2_0>Albertopolis<a2_0/>", a cultural and scientific quarter. Three major national museums are there: <a3_0>the Victoria and Albert Museum (for the applied arts)<a3_0/>, the Natural History Museum and the Science Museum. The National Portrait Gallery was founded in 1856 to house <a0_0>depictions of figures from British history<a0_0/>; its holdings now comprise the world's most extensive collection of portraits. The national gallery of British art is at Tate Britain, originally established <a4_0>as an annexe of the National Gallery<a4_0/> in 1897. <a1_0>The Tate Gallery<a1_0/>, as it was formerly known, also became a major centre for modern art; in 2000 this collection moved to Tate Modern, a new gallery housed in the former Bankside Power Station.
